title: How to Shoot Beautiful Outdoor Portraits That Simply "Glow"

steps.headline: Get a good camera: virtually any 35mm SLR or dslr camera with interchangeable lens will do.
steps.description: With the rise of digital cameras these are now VERY affordable. Consider purchasing a used camera and optics.

steps.headline: If possible use the normal (50mm lens).
steps.description: This lens has the best optics (by far) and allows you to shoot in dim light without a flash. DO NOT use a zoom lens - bad optics and they require too much light.

steps.headline: Set your camera at a low ISO--the lower the ISO, the better.
steps.description: 100 is best but 200 will do. DO NOT set it at 400 or above, as this creates "noise" and grain--unacceptable in fine portraits.

steps.headline: Shoot ONLY in the 30-45 minute window AFTER the suns sets or BEFORE it rises.
steps.description: This is by far the single most important factor in creating a fine portrait without expensive studio lighting. The quality of light during this time is unequaled. NEVER shoot portraits in full sun.

steps.headline: The only other option is the magical sky that occurs right after a rainstorm when the sky is clean and glowing - cloudy but brightening.
If you can see shadows the light is bad.
Put your subject outdoors at least 15 feet (4.6 m) or more in front of a natural backdrop of trees or tall bushes or anything natural.
steps.description: Do not put your subject closer than 15 feet (4.6 m) to anything - you want a blurred background with no distractions.

steps.headline: Get close to your subject - you want their face to fill most of the frame.
steps.description: Most people stand back way too far from their subject.

steps.headline: When the light is good and your subject is relaxed, shoot LOTS of exposures.
steps.description: The first 3 or 4 shots the model will be nervous (you are probably closer to them than they are used to) - Try keep them relaxed and smiling. Ask them to look slightly away from the camera - they should be looking at your shoulders or just a foot or two to your side. For a great portrait take several images with the same pose.

steps.headline: When you develop the film insist on Matte or Luster finish.
steps.description: DO NOT get glossy - portraits always look better in matte finish.

text: Get a good camera: virtually any 35mm SLR or dslr camera with interchangeable lens will do. With the rise of digital cameras these are now VERY affordable. Consider purchasing a used camera and optics. If possible use the normal (50mm lens). This lens has the best optics (by far) and allows you to shoot in dim light without a flash. DO NOT use a zoom lens - bad optics and they require too much light. Set your camera at a low ISO--the lower the ISO, the better. 100 is best but 200 will do. DO NOT set it at 400 or above, as this creates "noise" and grain--unacceptable in fine portraits. Shoot ONLY in the 30-45 minute window AFTER the suns sets or BEFORE it rises. This is by far the single most important factor in creating a fine portrait without expensive studio lighting. The quality of light during this time is unequaled. NEVER shoot portraits in full sun. The only other option is the magical sky that occurs right after a rainstorm when the sky is clean and glowing - cloudy but brightening.  If you can see shadows the light is bad.  Put your subject outdoors at least 15 feet (4.6 m) or more in front of a natural backdrop of trees or tall bushes or anything natural. Do not put your subject closer than 15 feet (4.6 m) to anything - you want a blurred background with no distractions. Get close to your subject - you want their face to fill most of the frame. Most people stand back way too far from their subject. When the light is good and your subject is relaxed, shoot LOTS of exposures. The first 3 or 4 shots the model will be nervous (you are probably closer to them than they are used to) - Try keep them relaxed and smiling. Ask them to look slightly away from the camera - they should be looking at your shoulders or just a foot or two to your side. For a great portrait take several images with the same pose. When you develop the film insist on Matte or Luster finish. DO NOT get glossy - portraits always look better in matte finish.
